body:
@ewencp I took the RC artifact and applied your changes to test it. Running `gradle` works, but not `./gradlew build` or `./gradlew test`. 

I only see one commit here: 79c6cac. How many commits should I be seeing in this PR?
@ewencp OK, I got it, it works for me now. +1, LGTM.

Thanks for the patch. This looks reasonable. Just one minor comment. One of the benefits of logging all config values is that we can verify the expected value is indeed set, especially when the configs are set through config management systems like Puppet and Chef. Would it be useful to support logging the actual password say in debug mode?
LGTM :+1:

Yes, that's right. However, this seems to only happen when the controller fails over and there is an uncompleted partition reassignment. This should be rare. So, I am wondering if it's worth optimizing this case.
@guozhangwang This addresses the minor setup issue you noticed recently when following the quickstart instructions in the testing readme

@granders @hachikuji The integration test now passes with no data loss (tested 3 times, and previously it breaks every time). The fix is not optimal such that it maintains a separate offset map for new consumer to commit, as mentioned above the optimal solution would be not unifying the interfaces of old / new consumers and re-work MM with only the new clients.
Thanks! LGTM.
LGTM
LGTM, thanks.

In addition to allowing , in principal option, I made some minor changes like not using a single instance of authorizer which resulted in list after add/remove reporting inconsistent acls sometimes. I also added all as a valid option for all resources.
@gwenshap @guozhangwang I've updated this with trunk and it's now stable as far as I can tell (passed many times in a row).
One minor question, otherwise LGTM!
Ping @hachikuji for reviews.

Also, not sure that I understand the issue with making authorizer a single instance. To list after add, one will need to run the AclCommand again, which will create a new instance of authorizer, right?
Also, in AclCommandTest, could you simulate an ssl user by including comma in the user name?

@junrao I caught my self following a pattern where I would add,remove a principal and then execute list to check what was the final out come so I added that as the default behavior i.e. Everytime we add,remove acls successfully we immediately execute list and show the output to user. 

So without the reinitialization I saw every now and then I run into following situation:

bin/kafka-acls.sh --authorizer kafka.security.auth.SimpleAclAuthorizer --authorizer-properties zookeeper.connect=localhost:2181 --add --allow-principal User:test1 --allow-principal User:test3 --allow-hosts host1 --deny-principal User:BadBob --deny-hosts bad-host --operations Read --topic test1 --deny-principal User:Alice
Adding following acls for resource: Topic:test1
    User:BadBob has Deny permission for operations: Read from hosts: bad-host
    User:test1 has Allow permission for operations: Read from hosts: host1
    User:test3 has Allow permission for operations: Read from hosts: host1
    User:Alice has Deny permission for operations: Read from hosts: bad-host

Following is list of acls for resource: Topic:test1

Which is a confusing behavior. I can remove the list after add/remove but that is just pushing the problem to user. Let me know if you think otherwise.
Added SSL principal in AClCommandTest
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Comments addressed, also made wakeupEnabled flag volatile.
LGTM

LGTM.
Committing to trunk and cherrypicking to 0.9.0, since this is a small but important change.

Some general comments:

1) We could also change all the hrefs to the 0.9.0 java docs in api.html (e.g. new producer section).
2) We could remove the migration section as a whole since it is from xx -> 0.8, or change the section as "if your current version is older than 0.8.0, before upgrade to 0.9.0 you need to do a one-time migration following instructions here {href}" in the upgrade.html.

@junrao Yes it is rare. After Guozhang opened this ticket, I recognized that the problem exists and took the opportunity to get familiar with controller code by implementing the patch. I don't have a strong opinion on whether we need this patch or not.
See #492 for checkstyle quick fix
Sorry about that @granthenke, not sure how I missed that. LGTM.
@junrao and @guozhangwang - addressed your suggestions.

Cherry picking to 0.9.0 failed with some conflicts, will do an manual commit.

EDIT: since 2752 is not committed to 0.9.0, we do not need to cherry pick it either.

@ewencp not a problem at all. The builds are taking longer and longer, and on Jenkins they are piling up. I have added failing fast to the build refactoring work I am doing for KAFKA-2787. See the initial work in #477.

That way waiting for the build to commit wont be as painful.

@granthenke Awesome, those will be very welcome improvements. Moving rat up to run earlier probably isn't too bad since people aren't adding new files that often. I'd be wary about making too much stuff fail fast though -- checkstyle in particular is really annoying if it runs before tests.
Also the auto generated data table seems ill-formated in browser (or is it only my browser)? http://kafka.apache.org/090/documentation.html#producerapi
@guozhangwang 2752 didn't go on 0.9.0, it shouldn't need cherry-picking
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Thanks for the patch. Good catch! LGTM.

@guozhangwang This looks good to me. Probably good for @hachikuji  to take a quick look since he is more familiar with the new consumer.

Also, it would be good to verify the hard bounce test case (it sounds like only the clean bounce was verified)
@guozhangwang Only question I have is whether we should be clearing the offset map on rebalances? If we don't clear it, wouldn't that cause us to commit offsets from older generations?
@hachikuji Good point. Instead of clearing on rebalance, I would prefer clearing right after each commit since that is simpler.
@guozhangwang Yep, that works too. LGTM.
Merged to both trunk and 0.9.0 branch.
Thanks for your comments. I will fix them later today.

LGTM except some commenting.

I feel the lower-level tasks => clients logic is a bit too complex, but admit it is quite tricky to handle various considerations:

1) the number of threads on each clients.
2) the previous assigned tasks on each clients.
3) try to not duplicating assignments across clients.

Actually for 3), I feel it is may not always be optimal do this, for example there are some discussions about partition assignment (currently we follow the same principle to distribute the partition replicas):

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-1736
@granders Ping for initial review.
LGTM. Merging to trunk only.
Will this change will make another caller of Selector, Sender.run(), to not throw Exceptions any more? (line 130)
LGTM. @junrao, you can commit after system tests pass on this branch :+1:

Sender may not get exception from Selector, but can get it from other places. However, it seems that we need to clean up Selectable since it never throws IOException in poll(). Will file a followup jira for that.
LGTM.
@junrao do you mind committing this?
Thanks for the patch. LGTM.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM

@junrao With regards to the logging, do you mean if logging is at DEBUG level? I'm not sure, personally. Is it not enough to know if the password has been set or not (which the current implementation does)? I would prefer to go with the current simpler and safer implementation to start with and add the optional logging if people ask for it. Thoughts? cc @gwenshap

@benstopford I had one comment about a possible way to simplify the current port logic, but otherwise looks good to me. Hopefully @junrao can also take a look since he's more familiar with security than I am
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
@junrao @gwenshap @guozhangwang  Would any of you have a chance to review this?
LGTM.
Merged to both trunk and 0.9.0.

Thanks @granthenke , there is a ticket created for this test failure:  

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2815

could you change the PR title with this JIRA?
Thanks. LGTM.
@guozhangwang Fixed the title. Thanks for notifying me of the jira.

This PR seems to accidentally try to merge trunk into 0.8.2 branch. Due to the hundreds of files this changes, its impossible to review.

Can you close this and open as PR to the correct branch?

I think it is a bad idea to log a password, ever.

Organizations with strong security requirements will be unable to log at debug/trace level if we start logging passwords.
@gwenshap OK, so we're in agreement.
This change LGTM now. The test failure doesn't look related. It would be great if @gwenshap or @junrao could merge it (assuming that they're happy with it).

Isn't it weird that PassWord.toString() returns a constant and not the actually value? That may be unexpected during debugging. The issue seems really just with logging. So it probably makes more sense to hide the password only during logging.

@junrao I agree that it's a bit weird, but because of the way we deal with values inside a Map, it's a bit easy to leak the information if we don't override `toString`. Note that the recommended way to deal with passwords for the paranoid is even stricter than this. The Java security tutorials typically use a char[] so that it can be cleared after usage.

@junrao I think the idea was to prevent anyone from accidentally printing the password. This way if you call password.value, you get the actual password - but just using the variable as a string will prevent accidental printing.
LGTM.
Ok, we can leave it as it is for now. However, be aware some places do have complex config management systems with different layers. A password may be set, but incorrectly.

The issue with the original patch was also very easy to miss because if you had built the project before, you'd have stale jar files that would make it look like everything continues to run ok. I checked this out into a fresh copy of the repo and ran the tests to make sure it works.
@hachikuji @guozhangwang I have updated the PR, do you mind taking a look?
LGTM.
@gwenshap @granders pinging again :)
Closing until rebased and cleaned up a bit. Will re-open soon.
LGTM

This was merged, but asfbot didn't close this...

Feel free to close.
@hachikuji I have added warning as part of #447 to avoid rebase conflict. @guozhangwang do you mind taking a look at this.
LGTM

@junrao The reason I did not add the check in BaseConsumer's OldConsumer is that by design its receive() function is always supposed to return a record, or throws an exception; plus check-and-next does not work either since the next() will call hasNext() again and concurrent thread may append the shutdown trunk in between (this is rare though). So instead we can safely catch and terminate the process in ConsoleConsumer.
LGTM. Merged to both trunk and 0.9.0.
@SinghAsDev Left two nitpick comments. Overall, LGTM.
@gwenshap Trivial fix, just took awhile to get the jenkins tests sorted out: http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/172/ This needs to be double applied to trunk + 0.9.0.
LGTM
LGTM, leave to @granders to take a look.
@guozhangwang Thanks for taking a look. I've also got some bounce tests that I'll probably add later today. They helped to find the deadlock error.

@guozhangwang Ping for review. As discussed, I tried to attack this from both sides of the deadlock. I refactored Partition to not hold the leaderIsrUpdateLock when completed the delayed requests, and I refactored GroupMetadataManager to divide storage into two calls so that we didn't need to hold the group metadata lock when doing the actual append.  Both solutions are... a little ugly.
I can't really comment on the Python but the logic looks good to me.

Yeah, looks like the main problem is that MiniKDC generates its own KRB5 file and doesn't take any inputs regarding what to put there.

Since MiniKDC is a single file, perhaps we can just fork it into our tools package and modify the part that generates KRB5? Maybe fix the annoying bug in the log (hostname:hostname rather than host:port...) while we are at it. This will also get rid of Hadoop dependency that I don't like.

Another option is just to move our system tests to use a real Kerberos install on the VM. It will also give us debug tools like klist and kinit, which will be useful.
Ahh.. looks like it is no longer needed.
@guozhangwang This is the timeout parameter discussed earlier

@gwenshap I needed this to get around having to redefine the entire `start_node` method. The approach is pretty hacky for now -- it just allows for hooking in by either rewriting the full `start_cmd` method or by doing string manipulations to extend it -- but provides enough of a hook to make the classes reusable without huge code duplication. Eventually I'd like a better solution (e.g. standardize how we run services so we can easily do things like modify environment variables, add extra command flags, etc), but this at least makes it possible to do _something_.

I've got working tests in a muckrake patch using this patch.
Also, this is trunk only, no need to double apply to 0.9.0.
LGTM
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
@junrao @ewencp Added a comment to reference metadata stall issue
